habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is now Extinct. It has not been seen in the wild since 1992, despite surveys. The most recent survey was in 2017. The last captive animal died in 2002.
range: This species was endemic to Raiatea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). It has not been located since 1992 despite surveys (most recently in 2017). The last captive animal died in 2002.
conservationActions: The species was bred in captivity, but the last captive animal died in 2002.

rationale: After the introduction of the carnivorous snail, Euglandina rosea, in the late 1980s, Partula atilis began declining rapidly. It has not been located since the 1980s and is believed to have been driven to extinction by E. rosea, finally disappearing around 1991–1992. The IUCN extinction assessment tools were used to analyse the available data for this species (see the Supplementary Material). The weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 0.99–1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment.
habitat: Partula atilis was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to the carnivorous snail Euglandina rosea, which was introduced onto the island in the late 1980s.
population: This species has been Extinct since around 1991–1992.
range: This species was endemic to Raiatea, Society Islands. It has not been located since the 1980s and is believed to have been driven to extinction by introduced predators (Euglandina rosea) around 1991–1992.
conservationActions: No conservation actions in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

rationale: Partula crassilabris was endemic to Raiatea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). After the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) in the late 1980s, native Partulid species began disappearing rapidly. This species has not been located since the 1980s, and it is believed to have been driven to extinction by E. rosea around 1991–1992. The IUCN extinction assessment tools were used to analyse the available data for this species (see the Supplementary Material). The weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 0.99–1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment.
habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is believed to have become extinct around 1991–1992.
range: This species was endemic to Raiatea, Society Islands. It has not been located since the 1980s and is believed to have been driven to extinction by introduced predators (specifically Euglandina rosea) in 1991–1992.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

The weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 0.99–1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment.

threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).

habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is believed to have been extinct since 1991–1992.
range: This species was endemic to Raiatea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). It has not been located since the 1980s and is believed to have been driven to extinction by the introduced predator, Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea), around 1991–1992.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

rationale: Partula levistriata was endemic to Raiatea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). After the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) in the late 1980s, native Partulid species began disappearing rapidly. This species has not been located since the 1980s and is believed to have been driven to extinction by E. rosea around 1991–1992. habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is believed to have become extinct around 1991–1992.
range: This species was endemic to Raiatea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). It has not been located since the 1980s and is believed to have been driven to extinction by the introduced predator, Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea), around 1991–1992.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

rationale: Partula lutea was endemic to Bora Bora in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). The carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) was introduced into Bora Bora around 1986. Rosy Wolf Snail was responsible for mass extinctions of Partulids on other islands, and it is likely that the P. lutea went extinct in the years between the introduction of E. rosea and the surveys in 1991, when no live individuals were found and the only shells were old and chalky. No Partulids were seen during a botanical expedition in 2006 (J.-Y. Meyer pers. comm.) or a Partulid survey in 2017.
habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is believed to have been driven to extinction before 1991.
range: This species was endemic to Bora Bora in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). It has not been located since the introduced predator Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) was introduced to the island before 1991, despite surveys (most recently in 2017).
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

rationale: Partula producta was endemic to Tahiti in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). After the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) to Tahiti in 1977, the species began to disappear rapidly as a result of predation. No live individuals were found in its range valley during searches in the 1980s and 1990s, or during the intensive surveys on the main island of Tahiti Nui 2003–2019. The species has probably been extinct since about 1980. The IUCN extinction assessment tools were used to analyse the available data for this species (see the Supplementary Material). The weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment.
habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is believed to have been driven to extinction in around 1980.
range: This species was endemic to Tahiti in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). Its distribution was restricted to the south-west of the island. After the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) to Tahiti in 1977, Partula producta began to disappear rapidly as a result of predation. No live individuals were found during searches in the 1980s and 1990s, or during the intensive surveys on the main island of Tahiti Nui between 2003 and 2019.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

rationale: Partula protracta was endemic to Raiatea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).

rationale: Partula bilineata was endemic to the island of Taha'a in the Society Islands French Polynesia). After the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) in the late 1980s, the native Partulid species on this island began to disappear as a result of predation. No live individual Partulids were found in the surveys of 1994, and none have been seen during scientific expeditions to high altitude areas since then (J.-Y. Meyer, pers. comm.), most extensively in 2017. The IUCN extinction assessment tools were used to analyse the available data for this species (see the Supplementary Material). The weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 0.98–1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment.
habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is thought to have been driven to extinction before 1994.
range: This species was endemic to Taha'a in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). It has not been located since the predatory Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) was introduced to the island before 1994, despite surveys in 2017.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

rationale: Partula aurantia was endemic to Moorea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). The carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) was introduced onto the island in 1977 and had an immediate disastrous impact on P. aurantia. This was the first Partula species to become Extinct as a result of this predation. No live individuals of Partula aurantia were found during the intensive surveys of the 1980s or in 2005. The IUCN extinction assessment tools were used to analyse the available data for this species (see the Supplementary Material). The weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 0.98–1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment.
habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) was introduced onto the island in 1977 and led to the extinction of Partula aurantia later that year..
population: This species has been extinct since 1977.
range: This snail was endemic to Moorea, Society Islands. It has not been located since the 1977 and is believed to have been driven to extinction by introduced predators (Euglandina rosea).
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.

rationale: Partula dolorosa was endemic to Raiatea in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). After the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) in the late 1980s, native Partulid species began disappearing rapidly. By 1992 there were few left, and no live individuals of this species were found during surveys in 1994, 2000 or 2017, or during subsequent scientific expeditions to high altitudes. The IUCN extinction assessment tools were used to analyse the available data for this species (see the Supplementary Material). Although the average probability of extinction (P(E)) is 0.896, suggesting the species is borderline CR(PE)/EX (due to relatively limited sampling of its upland range), the weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 0.93–1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment. Given the widespread nature of the invasive predators on the island, continued survival of P. dolorosa seems highly unlikely.
habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is now extinct. It has not been located since 1992. The last captive animal died in 1993.
range: This species was endemic to Raiatea, Society Islands. It has not been located since 1992, despite surveys (most recently in 2017). The last captive animal died in 1993.
conservationActions: A small number of individuals were maintained in captivity, but the last one died in 1993.

rationale: Partula eremita was endemic to Taha'a in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). After the introduction of the carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail  (Euglandina rosea) in the late 1980s, the native Partulid species on this island began to disappear. No live Partulids were found in the surveys of 1994, and none have been seen during scientific expeditions to high altitude areas since then (J.-Y. Meyer pers. comm.); the most recent survey was in 2017. The IUCN extinction assessment tools were used to analyse the available data for this species (see the Supplementary Material). The weighted probability of extinction of both the threats and records and surveys models combined is 0.98–1.00, supporting the Extinct assessment.
habitat: This was a forest species.
threats: The extinction of this species is attributed to predation by the introduced carnivorous Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea).
population: The species is believed to have been driven to extinction before 1994.
range: This species was endemic to Taha'a in the Society Islands (French Polynesia). It has not been located since the predatory Rosy Wolf Snail (Euglandina rosea) was introduced to the island sometime before 1994. The most recent surveys were in 2017.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place or needed for this species, as it is now Extinct.
